conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, analyze the motion based on the acceleration-time graph.
The particle starts from rest, meaning the initial velocity is zero.
The acceleration is positive initially (from 0 to t0), then decreases to zero, becomes negative, and increases back to positive (from t0 to 2t0).
From 0 to t0/2: Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to a0. The particle is accelerating positively.
From t0/2 to t0: Acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0. The velocity continues to increase but at a decreasing rate.
From t0 to 3t0/2: Acceleration becomes negative, starting from 0 to -a0. Velocity decreases as the particle starts to slow down.
From 3t0/2 to 2t0: Acceleration increases linearly from -a0 to 0. The particle continues to slow down.
The velocity-time graph is the integral of the acceleration-time graph.
Velocity reaches a maximum when the acceleration first becomes zero (at t0).
The particle continues to move in the positive direction until the velocity becomes zero again.
The position is the integral of the velocity.
The particle is farthest from the starting point when it reaches its maximum displacement.
This occurs when the velocity becomes zero again after reaching a maximum positive value.
The particle reaches its maximum displacement (farthest from the starting point) when the velocity becomes zero after increasing and then decreasing.
This happens at 3t0/2, as shown in the second graph where the velocity returns to zero.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at 3t0/2.
